rComments: Enthusiastic professors! If you get into the topic, lectures are very engaging. Make the effort to go to office hours â€“ he is very interesting and his suggestions for my final essay made it a very fun paper to write. I found his class overall to not be difficult (two 2p papers, two 5p papers, 'cancelled' final) but rather enjoyable & enlightening.

As nice and intelligent as this guy is, the class was boring. I could not stay awake. Plus there were a lot of reading assignments, few of which we actually mentioned in class. However, he grades on effort so if you show up and write a decent paper, you'll get a good grade.

He does not believe in the American style of testing and grading, midterm was done as a class in a discussion forum (everyone got A's), all he expects is that you keep up with the reading and listening assignments. If it's obvious you aren't making an attempt, you don't get the grade. Quirky Italian that he is, he keeps the lectures interesting.

This guy does not deserve to be teaching for a UC, or any school.  Unfortunately he has little or no criteria by which he bases his evaluations of his students, and accordingly grading by Mr. Spagnolo is purely subjective.  If you're one of those kids who can pretend to be interested in a vague, off topic, unfocussed, boring and under researched lecture then you will undoubtedly receive an A (you need not even turn in a final if he likes you enough).  But, if you voice your concerns you may not fair so well

His class has to be the easiest class at UCSC. There are 9 weekly responses and a midterm project. NO FINAL!! Spagnolo is such a nice man and he really cares about his students, although his lectures can get a little boring.

He was the worst professor I've ever had. The lectures were random as ****. He's a great guy, funny, quirky Italian, but not such a good prof. His class is easy if you finally figure out what he wants. He e-mails a lot. I skipped about five classes and it didn't matter. No section!
